story:
We all know that Macmillan are a great charity and they make a significant difference to so many peoples lives in the final moments. 

For my personal story, I lost my mum when I was 3, for the past 16 years I have missed her every second of every day. My only comfort is that in her final moments she was well cared for and looked after by Macmillan Cancer Support. I’ve always wanted to give something back and help this amazing charity. My mum would have been 55 this year, mine and Callum’s challenge is to run 55 miles each in the month of February to not only remember her, but to raise awareness for how amazing Macmillan Cancer Support is and how much we appreciate how much they help people every single day. 

Callum wanted to join me in this challenge as he also has lost family close to him that were supported by this amazing charity. We all know what a difference they can make and the support and comfort they can give, not only to the person suffering but to their family and friends. Even the smallest amount can make a difference, everyday of training and running, we will not only be thinking of our loved ones but also of others that suffer this heartbreaking disease. Any donations will be greatly appreciated.

story:
Hey! 

I've spent most of lockdown trying to level up my art skills (if you can call them that) and a few weeks back I posted a picture of the Harland and Wolff Cranes, and a few kind people said they'd love to buy a copy. Crazy, right?

I never planned to make money from my doodles, but I did want to get a copy of this picture to anyone who would like it! I printed a copy myself onto a mug (see gallery above) and I love the results.

So let's make an exchange. When you make a donation to the wonderful Macmillan Cancer Support charity via this page, the thank you email will contain a link to a digital copy of the Harland and Wolff crane doodle. You'll need to make sure you provide an email address when you make your donation. You'll get three files altogether:

  • Original art with textured paper background
  • Original art with white background
  • Original art with white background (without text).

The image file is 1000x1000px, or 10"x10" at 300DPI.

The donation receipt will contain a link to a Google Drive folder with the images for you. You may need to wait a few minutes for the email, and you may need to copy and paste the address into your favourite browser!

Why would I want a digital image?

With your digital image, you can take it to your favourite printers and do whatever you like with it! Websites like VistaPrint will allow you to create prints, canvas, mousemats, mugs, magnets, stickers, greeting cards - you name it.
The original image is 10x10" - you may be able to take it larger than this without losing any quality, but I cannot guarantee it.
For any item that isn't square, you may need to do some further image editing at your end. 

Please consider the digital file a "thank you" from me, to do with as you like. I cannot offer technical support, and obviously cannot offer refunds! :) The digital file is yours to keep, whether you print it, use it as a phone wallpaper, or create a dart board! And if you've no idea what to do with a digital file, that's also OK! Your donation is massively appreciated.

Why Macmillan Cancer Support?

As some of you may know, in 2016 we lost my mum, Jennifer Nesbitt to cancer. Her loss was felt by many - a mum, a wife, a sister, a friend and so much more to many people. Everything happened quite quickly, and naturally the hardest part of losing someone is those last few days when you value your privacy and final days together. This is where Macmillan Care at Antrim Area Hospital really helped our family, giving us a dedicated and private room to share my mums final days with her. Places like this rely on charity donations - whether it's to buy a chair to seat an extra family member, or pay a nurse who's there to lend a shoulder to cry on. They offer a safe and special place to families in the most difficult times in their life, and every penny of this fundraise will help to continue the amazing support they provide.

A Word from Macmillan & JustGiving

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

Thank You

Thank you so, so much. It means a lot to me that some of you actually wanted to have something I drew in your house. But it means even more to me that some of you may be kind enough to throw a few quid this way and support an amazing cause on this 5 year anniversary of my mums passing.

Matt x

story:
As most people know - I am LAZY! To me, it's about time that changed.

  I used to be in great shape because I never stopped. Whether it be walking/cycling out with friends, working or even kickboxing at one point - I was always on my feet doing something. 

  Now? Well, I had a bike accident and messed my knee up leading me to a mainly desk-based job then I had Paisley - she keeps me on my toes but not enough to do anything😅 Though I am still slightly restricted with my knee, I aim to achieve!

  From the 1st of February to the 11th May, I (and Paisley in tow!) will be walking once a day, sharing my routes (using the tag #walk100) and increasing the length daily. That's over the course of 100 days. 

  Then I thought - I've tried doing this before about a year ago and gave up. I had no motivation. This time I will persist AND benefit others through doing so - Not only am I doing this for my own goals, I am doing this 100 day walking quest for Macmillan Cancer. We have all experienced cancer in one way or another. Whether you're a fighter, survivor or an unfortunate mourner - cancer has affected us all. All the money that is donated to this just giving page will go straight to Macmillan to help make a difference! Big or small, all amounts will add up to progress.

story:
I will be running a February Fifty! Thanks to inspiration and circumstances, I feel that it's important at this time to fundraise for charity, and what better way than to run 50 miles in a month?! (there's a few better ways but oh well)

Cancer is something that my family and I have unfortunately faced head on very recently, especially regarding my auntie Jackie. Jackie Hughes unfortunately died on the 29th December 2020, after a long battle with breast cancer. She had become a heroic figure in her local community, due to her unwavering positivity and toughness, raising over £2,000 in a personal pledge in her memory. She especially loved running, taking part in many races around the North East, inspiring her friends and family to run with her in the process - and now it's my turn. This challenge is usually known as the Run50 Challenge for Maggie's Centres, but because this is being done in her memory, I am instead deciding to donate proceeds to Macmillan Cancer Support. This charity was fundamental in their care towards Jackie, which myself and the family are eternally grateful for.

As if not motivation enough, I have also recently learnt the news that my dad has been diagnosed with mouth cancer. Whilst very tough news to hear, the consultant has ensured us that this is both very treatable and curable - I can only hope for a swift recovery, especially in such an enormous year for my dad.

My target is £250, but I will be grateful for every single penny donated, especially in these financially straining times we are all under. Also, a special thanks goes out to Verity Stroud for inspiring me to give this a try, as she completed her Run50 Challenge with 12 days to spare (!!!!!)

story:
My dad, Ray was diagnosed with Bowel cancer back in 2007, following treatment and support from Rotherham hospital he made a full recovery. 

Early in 2016 Ray received the news of a diagnosis of Stomach cancer. Although being told this was terminal, Ray continued to live life to the full, spending time with his family and friends and pottering in his garden. Ray received  treatment and support from Weston Park hospital in Sheffield and more recently Rotherham Hospice until he sadly lost his battle and passed away on the 16th of January this year. 

Throughout his battle with Cancer Ray and my mum, Carol, received unbelievable support from Macmillan Cancer support, they do fantastic work helping people affected by and living with Cancer.

The money donated here will go towards supporting the brilliant work they do for others.

story:
Thank you for visiting my Game Heroes page. 

Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, they are right there with you.

I started doing these events multiple times every year to raise
money in memory of my mum Elaine. From 24 hour streams to Pass The Torch marathons with other streamers that are invited to join and take part.

Macmillan not only helped my mum cope with her diagnosis and
help my family through what is still the worst point of our lives, but they were there for me when my mum passed away and the time that followed, I was a broken and shattered image of the person I used to be and I wouldn't be here today if it wasn't for them.

The limit on how long a page can be active is by default the 31st
of December 2026 but I intend to do these marathon streams for as long as I live and for every single second watched, penny donated and times this event is shared about, I want you to know I am eternally grateful for everything.

- MadeOfSandL // L Lawliet

story:
So a symptom after pregnancy is a lot of women’s hair falls out. Even though my hair is so thick it’s very annoying having clumps of hair in my hands every time I touch it. Plus I would be getting a hair cut from my wife anyway. So I have decided to do something I have never done before. I’m going to shave it all off! 

As much as this would be just as good to do for fun, please help me raise awareness and money for a very special charity. I have known people who have passed away from heart conditions, and some are surviving after the effects of serious heart issues.

  Sadly our friend Julie Luff lost her Dad, Pat this January from a heart attack after surviving heart operations a few years ago. Unfortunately the dreaded Covid that has hit so many struck and his fight was over. 

Please help me raise money in his name for an amazing charity. 

At 14:00 on Sunday 31st of January my wife will put the clippers to my hair. Please support me.


Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

story:
In September 2011, I lost my Grampy to a heart condition. He was the kindest, most gentle man in the world,and was/ is one of the most inspirational men in my life. I miss him every day and this year marks 10 years since his passing. At his funeral, we accepted donations to the British heart foundation in his memory, so I thought to mark this heartbreaking milestone, I would focus my fundraising efforts on the British heart foundation again this year. This march, I, a self-confessed chocoholic, am taking part in the Dechox challenge, giving up all chocolate for a whole month! 

In 2020, the British heart foundation made the devastating decision to cut their research budget in half, as an after effect of the COVID - 19 pandemic. So they have never needed donations (no matter how small) as much as now, because, despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers.

If you could please donate to my page and support me as I go completely coco free for a whole month.

story:
The welfare of animals is fundamentally important to me,  growing up I was surrounded by two Labrador dogs Susie & Bella, a poodle, Simon, rabbits , Sweep Nibbler and even goldfish Fred & Ginger (sorry I made their names up).

Once I had grown up that journey continued with our beloved dog, Chester a Yorkshire Terrier who we said goodbye to in 2019 and now we now have such pleasure from our latest arrival Louie again a Yorkie who turned 1 in October 2020.  He is the “well” in our wellbeing and has brought us much hope and joy during the darkest times during lockdown.  

I have supported Guide Dogs for the blind along with some other charities over the years as they do such amazing work with the Labrador breed that ultimately means many partially sighted or blind people can become fully independent.  Having two grandparents that lost there sight and seeing them struggle through their older years brings this very close to home!

story:
In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
In the space of an hour, a Marie Curie nurse can give a great deal of care to someone living with a terminal illness. That's why this February, we're asking all SPAR CO colleagues to take on the SPAR-tan 60 minute challenge. 

The challenge is simple, complete an activity that challenges you for 60 minutes, donate £5 to this page and nominate 5 colleagues from Central Office to take on the challenge too!

Whether you want to run, star jump or row for 60 minutes, you can make this challenge your own and help us raise money for our national charity partner Marie Curie.

Thank you for your support!

Did you know?

As little as £20 can fund an hour of nursing care for someone with a terminal illness in the comfort of their own home.

£32 can pay for a call to the Marie Curie Support line, meaning someone in need can pick up the phone and receive practical information and emotional support.

£180 will pay for a Marie Curie nurse to look after someone with a terminal illness for a full nine-hour shift

£400 will pay for someone to stay in Marie Curie's Hampstead hospice for 24 hours, so they can receive the hands-on care they need in their final days,

Thank you for your support.

story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

eventName: Walk 1,000 Miles in 2021 for the RNLI
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
In 2020, I spent a lot of time walking in my local community and managed to cover a total of 800 miles! This got me thinking...could I cover 1,000 miles in a year?

Well, in 2021, the year where I turn 81 years of age, I'll be doing exactly that, and I'll be looking to raise funds for the Royal National Lifeboat Institution along the way.

As a lifelong supporter of the RNLI, I've come to learn the importance of the emergency service they provide and how they provide support not just to people who live by the coast.

I'll be starting my challenge on the 1st February, which means I've got to cover 80-85 miles each month.....wish me luck, and please make a donation on my fundraising page, no matter how big or small.

Thank you.

A little bit about the charity I'm supporting.....

The nearest Lifeboat Station to the Midlands might be over 100 miles away, but with 87% of residents of the Midlands visiting the coast each year, you don't have to live by the sea to support the RNLI.

The RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown.

Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped.

Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited.The coasts of Wales and North West England are popular tourist destinations for millions of holidaymakers from the Midlands and we want to keep those coasts a safe place for everyone to visit.

The average lifeboat station in Wales, North West England and Isle of Man costs £159,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus.

We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.

When you and your loved visit the coast, we will always be there to keep you safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on British coasts.

Please help us fulfil that mission.

Thank you.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story: I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.
